title: Leading Non-Market Strategy in African Business Environments
xlist: Same As: MGT 620, section 01
description: Non-market strategy supposedly plays a larger role in “institutional voids” countries, where adroit networking serves as a substitute for strategic management. Studying non-market strategy in an African context offers a rich ground for granular treatment of the subject, greater appreciation of its nature and nuances, and critical insights and new perspectives on theories and practices. With a population of more than a billion—many of them young—a significantly large middle class, better macroeconomic management, and positively evolving democracies, Africa has become an intriguing prospect for international expansion and entrepreneurial ventures from and beyond the continent. China and, to a lesser extent, India, have so proactively seized on Africa’s potential that the former is being accused of a modern-day scramble for the continent. The U.K. recently launched a foray to bolster trade with Africa as soon as it exits the European Union. France remains entrenched in African trade and politics through its ties to francophone countries. Germany has warm trade relations with Africa. And indigenous concepts, such as Ubuntu and Africapitalism, offer new and innovative perspectives for theory development and strategic management. In this course students explore how non-market factors vary cross-nationally in an emerging (African) market environment; gain greater dexterity in analyzing, innovating, and applying conceptions of the non-market environment of a firm by exposure to markedly different cultural and institutional contexts; gain greater rigor in developing home and regional non-market strategy for international firms; and become more conscientious about ethical, leadership, and social responsibility considerations in the strategic management of a firm. Also MGT 620.
